title: Controlling the Solution Chemistry in Aqueous Phases During In Situ Microscopy
content: In situ microscopy such as liquid phase (scanning) transmission electron microscopy (LP-(S)TEM) or in situ X-ray characterization methods enables real time access to dynamic processes at the nanoscale. However, substantial inelastic scattering can alter the course of the experiment, i.e. via beam-induced heating [1] or radiolysis [2, 3]. Particularly the latter drives redox and acidity equilibria towards non-standard conditions [3, 4]. Additional parameters such as liquid flow affect these processes further [5], demanding for precise parameter assessment during experimental design and interpretation.
